pageData.text: The reproductive system creates <button class='glossary-text'>gametes</button>, which are cells that contain only half of the genetic materials, and then combines them to create offspring. This requires specialized tissue to produce the gametes. Humans carry their offspring inside of them while the embryos are developing. This requires a protective environment that allows for fetal development. Together, these specialized tissues make up the reproductive system.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: Testis - 25 minutes
Activity 2: Mammal Ovary - 20 minutes
Activity 3: Mammal Ovary Follicles - 20 minutes
Activity 4: Human Uterus - 15 minutes

pageData.text: Note: This exercise can be broken into multiple sessions by stopping between each activity.

text: Identify and describe the reproductive and supporting tissues of the male and female reproductive systems.
Observe and discuss the stages of follicular development.
Recognize and describe the tissue types of the uterine wall.
Identify cells involved in <button class='glossary-text'>sperm</button> production.

pageData.text: Ancient Greek philosophers thought the female reproductive system was an internal version of the male reproductive system: the vagina was an internal penis, the womb was an internal <button class='glossary-text'>scrotum</button>, and the <button class='glossary-text'>ovaries</button> were internal testicles. This one-sex model was considered the correct view of human anatomy until the late 17th century<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. Then the two-sex model was proposed, which acknowledged physical differences between male and female reproductive organs, and differences between masculinity and femininity. Contemporary research on biological maleness versus femaleness complicates, and may contradict, the two-sex model.

The difficulty in distinguishing between two sexes greatly impacts athletics, especially for females. The prevailing methods for determining if an athlete is female identify sex chromosomes and testosterone levels. However, some females have an intersex condition and feature a Y chromosome; and both males and females produce testosterone, and there is no standard for production levels in each sex. In the Olympics, if a female athlete is found to have an intersex condition, they must lower their testosterone levels before competing. Even though the World Medical Association has advised doctors not to administer testosterone-lowering interventions, female athletes have been denied eligibility in international games based on hormone levels. Currently, males in international sports are not required to undergo chromosomal testing or hormone monitoring to compete<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup>.
1Laqueur, T. (1992). Making sex: body and gender from the Greeks to Freud. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press, 1992. http://hdl.handle.net/2027/heb.31961.0001.001.

2Savulescu, J. (May 9, 2019). Ten ethical flaws in the Caster Semenya decision on intersex in sport. The Conversation.
https://theconversation.com/ten-ethical-flaws-in-the-caster-semenya-decision-on-intersex-in-sport-116448.

pageData.desc: Eight female athletes in competition attire waiting at the starting line of an outdoor track.
pageData.altText: Eight female athletes in competition attire waiting at the starting line of an outdoor track.

pageData.text: The male and female reproductive systems are controlled by hormones produced by the pituitary gland in the brain, and the reproductive organs themselves.

pageData.subTitle: Pituitary Gland
pageData.text: The pituitary gland secretes hormones that control the reproductive organs. It signals the production of sex hormones and controls ovulation and the menstrual cycle in women.

pageData.subTitle: The Reproductive Organs
pageData.text: These organs make, mature, and store gametes, or sex cells, in the human body. The male gametes are called sperm and female gametes are called ova or egg cells. Each gamete contributes half of an offspring’s DNA, providing genetic variation through sexual reproduction.

pageData.subTitle: Male reproductive system
pageData.text: Sperm is made in the seminiferous tubules and stored in the epididymis. It travels through the vas deferens, where it mixes with seminal fluids and passes through the urethra.

pageData.subTitle: Female reproductive system
pageData.text: Immature eggs are found in the ovaries where they mature and are released into the fallopian tubes. An egg travels down the tube to the uterus, where it either implants and develops into an embryo or is shed with the lining of the uterus at the end of a menstrual cycle.

In order to reproduce, the body produces <button class='glossary-text'>gametes</button>, cells that contain only half of the genetic materials. Both males and females have dedicated organs for this process, the <button class='glossary-text'>gonads</button>. In the female, <button class='glossary-text'>ova</button> (or eggs) are produced in the <button class='glossary-text'>ovaries</button>, and in the male, <button class='glossary-text'>sperm</button> is produced in the <button class='glossary-text'>testes</button>. The gonads are also responsible for the production of sex hormones, which play a dual role in the body. They prepare the body for reproduction, and during puberty, they stimulate the development of the <button class='glossary-text'>secondary sex characteristics</button>. This investigation focuses mainly on the areas where the gametes are being formed and where the fetus develops.

Male gametes are formed in the testes (see Figures 1 and 2). The testes are located in a pouch, the <button class='glossary-text'>scrotum</button>, which is located outside the body cavity. On the outside, the testis is covered by a two-layered tunic, the <button class='glossary-text'>tunica vaginalis</button>. This membrane has a similar structure as the <button class='glossary-text'>peritoneum</button>, which covers the abdominal cavity. This tunic is made up of two layers: the outer <button class='glossary-text'>parietal layer</button> and the inner <button class='glossary-text'>visceral layer</button>. Deep in the tunica vaginalis is a layer of dense connective tissue, the <button class='glossary-text'>tunica albuginea</button>, which forms fibrous partitions, the <button class='glossary-text'>septa</button>. The tunica albuginea contains blood vessels that provide the underlying tissue with nutrients and oxygen. It also contains lymph vessels that assist in draining excess fluid from the testis. This layer also contains the <button class='glossary-text'>efferent ductules</button>, which transport the mature sperm out of the testis.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Labeled cross section of the testis
Figure 2: A testis showing septa, blood vessels, interstitial cells, spermatozoa, and seminiferous tubules

pageData.text: Each septum divides the testis into <button class='glossary-text'>lobules</button>. These lobules contain the <button class='glossary-text'>seminiferous tubules</button>. These tubules are lined with epithelial cells, which produce the <button class='glossary-text'>spermatozoa</button>, or sperm cells. Each of these tubules has a distinct U shape and is connected to a <button class='glossary-text'>straight tubule</button> that then connects to the <button class='glossary-text'>rete testis</button>. This connects to the <button class='glossary-text'>efferent ductules</button> and then to the epididymis. These tubules are surrounded by blood vessels and <button class='glossary-text'>interstitial cells</button>, which produce the male sex hormone, testosterone.

pageData.question: The tunica albuginea contains blood and lymph vessels. Which of the following best describes the function of these vessels?

options.text: They provide nutrients and oxygen, as well as assist in draining excess fluid.
They produce the male sex hormone testosterone.
They facilitate the maturation of the female ova.
They produce the cuboidal cells surrounding an oocyte.
They enlarge the intercellular spaces into one large space.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The tunica albuginea contains blood vessels that provide the underlying tissue with nutrients and oxygen. The tunica albuginea contains lymph vessels that assist in draining excess fluid from the testis.

pageData.question: The tunica albuginea is made up of which of the following layer(s)?

options.text: outer parietal layer and the inner visceral layer
outer sperm layer and the inner visceral layer
outer parietal layer and the sperm visceral layer
outer parietal layer and the intercellular spaces

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: This tunic is made up of two layers: the outer parietal layer and the inner visceral layer.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Male gametes are formed in the testes. The testes are located in a pouch, the scrotum, which is located outside the body cavity. On the outside, the testis is covered by a two-layered tunic, the tunica vaginalis. This membrane has a similar structure to that of the peritoneum, which covers the abdominal cavity. Deep in the tunica vaginalis is a layer of dense connective tissue, the tunica albuginea, which forms fibrous partitions, the septa. The tunica albuginea contains blood vessels that provide the underlying tissue with nutrients and oxygen. It also contains lymph vessels that assist in draining excess fluid from the testis. This layer also contains the efferent ductules, which transport the mature sperm out of the testis.

img.alt: Figure 1: Labeled cross section of the testis

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Male gametes are formed in the testes. The testes are located in a pouch, the scrotum, which is located outside the body cavity. On the outside, the testis is covered by a two-layered tunic, the tunica vaginalis. This membrane has a similar structure to that of the peritoneum, which covers the abdominal cavity. Deep in the tunica vaginalis is a layer of dense connective tissue, the tunica albuginea, which forms fibrous partitions, the septa. The tunica albuginea contains blood vessels that provide the underlying tissue with nutrients and oxygen. It also contains lymph vessels that assist in draining excess fluid from the testis. This layer also contains the efferent ductules, which transport the mature sperm out of the testis.

img.alt: Figure 1: Labeled cross section of the testis

pageData.text: Female <button class='glossary-text'>gametes</button> are produced in the <button class='glossary-text'>ovaries</button>, which are located in the abdominal pelvic area (see Figure 3) and are suspended by <button class='glossary-text'>ovarian</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>broad ligaments</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>suspensory ligaments</button>, which also contain the blood vessels supplying the ovary.

pageData.desc: The female reproductive system labeled, the uterus and ovaries scheme, and the phases of the menstrual cycle
pageData.altText: Figure 3: The female reproductive system labeled, the uterus and ovaries scheme, and the phases of the menstrual cycle

pageData.text: The outer layer of <button class='glossary-text'>peritoneum</button> is made up of cuboidal epithelium, which sits on top of the <button class='glossary-text'>tunica albuginea</button>. The <button class='glossary-text'>ovaries</button> have an outer layer, the <button class='glossary-text'>cortex</button>, and an inner layer, the <button class='glossary-text'>medulla</button>, which is made up of loose connective tissue. The medulla contains blood vessels and nerves. The production and maturation of the female <button class='glossary-text'>ova</button>, or eggs, takes place in the cortex. This takes place in structures called <button class='glossary-text'>ovarian follicles</button>. The process of egg maturation starts with a <button class='glossary-text'>primary oocyte</button> (see Figure 4). This haploid cell has a large nucleus and starts off with a size of approximate 25 µm. During the maturation process, it grows to about 100 µm. At this point, the follicular cells divide and produce cuboidal cells surrounding the oocyte and are called the <button class='glossary-text'>primary follicle</button>. The cells in the follicular tissue become larger and form layers surrounding the developing oocyte. These cells surrounding the oocyte become rounded and grainy looking in appearance; they are called <button class='glossary-text'>granulosa cells</button>. Further divisions now enlarge the intercellular spaces into one large space, the <button class='glossary-text'>antrum</button>, which is filled with <button class='glossary-text'>follicular fluid</button>. At this point, the follicle becomes a <button class='glossary-text'>secondary follicle</button>. One of these secondary follicles is selected and goes through a maturation process during the first 14 days of the ovarian cycle and becomes a <button class='glossary-text'>tertiary follicle</button>, also known as a <button class='glossary-text'>Graafian follicle</button>, or <button class='glossary-text'>vesicular follicle</button>. At this point, the oocyte moves into the antrum. The outer layer of the tertiary follicle fuses with the outer layer of the ovary and opens up, releasing the oocyte. The empty tertiary follicle collapses, creating the <button class='glossary-text'>corpus luteum</button>, which slowly degenerates and is absorbed into the surrounding tissue.

pageData.desc: Ovaries with primary oocyte, granulosa cells, follicle, antrum, and oocyte nuclei labeled
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Ovaries with primary oocyte, granulosa cells, follicle, antrum, and oocyte nuclei labeled

pageData.question: Which of the following structures distinguishes a secondary follicle from a primary follicle?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A primary follicle does not have an antrum while a secondary follicle does.

pageData.question: Which of the following can be found in the antrum of a secondary follicle?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The antrum is filled with follicular fluid.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The process of egg maturation starts with a primary oocyte.  At this point, the follicular cells divide and produce cuboidal cells surrounding the oocyte and are called the primary follicle. The cells in the follicular tissue become larger and form layers surrounding the developing oocyte. These cells surrounding the oocyte become rounded and grainy looking in appearance; they are called granulosa cells. Further divisions now enlarge the intercellular spaces into one large space, the antrum, which is filled with follicular fluid. At this point, the follicle becomes a secondary follicle. One of these secondary follicles is selected and goes through a maturation process during the first 14 days of the ovarian cycle and becomes a tertiary follicle, also known as a Graafian follicle, or vesicular follicle.

img.alt: Figure 4: Ovaries with primary oocyte, granulosa cells, follicle, antrum, and oocyte nuclei labeled

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The process of egg maturation starts with a primary oocyte.  At this point, the follicular cells divide and produce cuboidal cells surrounding the oocyte and are called the primary follicle. The cells in the follicular tissue become larger and form layers surrounding the developing oocyte. These cells surrounding the oocyte become rounded and grainy looking in appearance; they are called granulosa cells. Further divisions now enlarge the intercellular spaces into one large space, the antrum, which is filled with follicular fluid. At this point, the follicle becomes a secondary follicle. One of these secondary follicles is selected and goes through a maturation process during the first 14 days of the ovarian cycle and becomes a tertiary follicle, also known as a Graafian follicle, or vesicular follicle.

img.alt: Figure 4: Ovaries with primary oocyte, granulosa cells, follicle, antrum, and oocyte nuclei labeled

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>uterus</button> (see <button class='resource-text'>Figure 3</button>) is the area where the fertilized egg attaches itself and develops into a fetus. The uterus is made up of three areas: the <button class='glossary-text'>fundus</button>, located superior to the entry of the fallopian tubes; the <button class='glossary-text'>cervix</button>, which separates the uterus from the vagina; and the <button class='glossary-text'>uterine body</button>, which makes up the main portion of the uterus.
The uterus is made up of three distinct layers:

text: The outer <button class='glossary-text'>perimetrium</button> consists mainly of fibrous tissue.

The <button class='glossary-text'>myometrium</button> (see Figure 5) sits under the perimetrium and consists of smooth muscle cells in three layers—an outer layer of longitudinal muscles, followed by a thick layer of circular muscles, and an inner layer of longitudinal muscles.

The <button class='glossary-text'>endometrium</button> is made up of simple columnar epithelium tissue on top of a layer of <button class='glossary-text'>lamina propria</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Uterine glands</button> are between the columnar epithelium. There are also two layers of the endometrium—<button class='glossary-text'>stratum functionalis</button>, which sheds off during each menstruation period, and <button class='glossary-text'>stratum basalis</button>, which creates a new functionalis after menstruation ends.

pageData.desc: Uterine glands, endometrium/lamina propria, columnar epithelium, and myometrium in the uterus
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Uterine glands, endometrium/lamina propria, columnar epithelium, and myometrium in the uterus

pageData.question: Which of the following is the layer of the uterus shed during each menstruation period?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The stratum functionalis, a layer of the uterus’ endometrium, is shed during each menstruation period.

pageData.question: Which of the following is the layer of the uterus that creates a new stratum functionalis after menstruation ends?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The stratum basalis creates a new stratum functionalis after menstruation ends.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The uterus is the area where the fertilized egg attaches itself and develops into a fetus. The uterus is made up of three areas: the fundus, located superior to the entry of the fallopian tubes; the cervix, which separates the uterus from the vagina; and the uterine body, which makes up the main portion of the uterus. The uterus is made up of three distinct layers. The outer perimetrium consists mainly of fibrous tissue. The myometrium sits under the perimetrium and consists of smooth muscle cells in three layers—an outer layer of longitudinal muscles, followed by a thick layer of circular muscles, and an inner layer of longitudinal muscles. The endometrium is made up of simple columnar epithelium tissue on top of a layer of lamina propria. Uterine glands are between the columnar epithelium. There are two layers of the endometrium, stratum functionalis, and stratum basalis, which creates a new functionalis after menstruation ends.

pageData.desc: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, set up the microscope. In Activities 1 through 4, you will place a slide on the stage and focus the tissue layers in the field of view. Then, record an image of the tissue under ideal magnification and identify the structures of the magnified tissue. Next, calculate the total magnification for ideal observation and compare the characteristics of each structure. You will repeat this until a total of 4 reproductive tissue slides have been observed.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for Introduction to Histology: Reproductive System (item number 580576) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company. Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
Read all the instructions for the laboratory activities before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing each activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Ensure that any broken or discarded microscope slides are disposed of properly. Put them in a hard-sided container (such as a small, sturdy cardboard box) before placing them in the household trash.

How to Handle, Store, and Repair Microscope Slides

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the structures of a testis from largest to smallest?
What is the role of interstitial cells in the testes?
Which of the following describes the function of the cortex and medulla of the ovaries, respectively?

options.text: egg maturation; circulatory and nervous system support

assestmentData.question: As the follicle surrounding an oocyte matures, which of the following structures is formed and fills with follicular fluid?
At which point in the oocyte maturation process does the oocyte move into the antrum?

options.text: when the secondary follicle matures into a tertiary follicle
when the primary follicle matures into a secondary follicle
when the cells surrounding the oocyte become rounded and grainy
four days after the formation of the secondary oocyte

assestmentData.question: Which of the following structures gives rise to the corpus luteum?

options.text: No intermediate container is necessary for slides disposal.

Select a work area that is near an electrical outlet if using a corded microscope.
Obtain all listed needed materials from your kit. (Remember: when carrying your microscope, grasp it by the arm and support the base.)
Familiarize yourself with your microscope. Identify its key parts. Consult the instructions that came with your microscope if you have any difficulty finding a specific part.
Note: If your microscope has an oil immersion (100×) objective, identify it, but do not use it during this investigation.

Be aware of your instructor’s directions for documenting your work. You may be asked to draw pictures and either photograph or scan them for submission, or you may need to take pictures through the microscope using a digital camera or mobile device. To learn how to take photos through the microscope, see the following video:
In Activity 1, you will observe a testis slide under the microscope.
Select the testis slide from the slide set.
Place it on the microscope stage.
Note: Remember, the label should be faceup on the left.
Center and focus the slide at the lowest power.
Scan through the slide until you come across a section that clearly shows the layers of the testis; use <button class='resource-text'>Figure 2</button> from the “Background” as a guide.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Now increase the magnification of the  microscope. Take or draw a picture of what you can distinguish, and indicate <button class='glossary-text'>septa</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>interstitial cells</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>spermatozoa</button>, seminiferous tubule, and blood vessels.

In Data Table 1, note what makes the parts of the testis you have labeled in Step 5 look different from each other. Also record the total magnification needed to best view the cells.
Total magnification = (eyepiece lens power) x (objective lens power)
Replace the slide in the slide box.
In Activity 2, you will observe an ovary slide under the microscope.
Select the mammal ovary slide from the slide set.
Place it on the microscope stage.
Center and focus the slide at the lowest power.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Scan through the slide until you come across a section that clearly shows the sections of the ovary with follicles. Take or draw a picture of the <button class='glossary-text'>cortex</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>medulla</button>. Now increase to a higher magnification.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take or draw a picture of what you can distinguish and indicate oocyte nuclei, follicle, the , a , and the .

In Data Table 2, note what makes the cells you have labeled in Step 5 look different from each other. Also record the total magnification needed to best view the cells.
Total magnification = (eyepiece lens power) x (objective lens power)
Replace the slide in the slide box.
In Activity 3, you will observe an <button class='glossary-text'>ovarian follicles</button> slide under the microscope
Select the mammal ovary follicles slide from the slide set.
Place it on the microscope stage.
Center and focus the slide at the lowest power.
Scan through the slide until you come across a section that clearly shows the follicles in different stages of development.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take or draw a picture of what you can distinguish, and indicate the <button class='glossary-text'>primary follicle</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>secondary follicle</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>tertiary follicle</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>corpus luteum</button>.

In Data Table 3, note what makes the cells you have labeled in Step 5 look different from each other. Adjust the magnification as needed, and record the total magnification needed to best view the cells.
Total magnification = (eyepiece lens power) x (objective lens power)
Replace the slide in the slide box.
In Activity 4, you will observe a <button class='glossary-text'>uterus</button> slide under the microscope.
Select the human <button class='glossary-text'>uterus</button> slide from the slide set.
Place it on the microscope stage.
Center and focus the slide at the lowest power.
Scan through the slide until you come across a section that clearly shows the sections of the uterus.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take or draw a picture of what you can distinguish, and indicate the myometrium, <button class='glossary-text'>endometrium</button>, uterine gland, and columnar epithelium. Increase the magnification to verify these structures, but take or draw the picture at a lower magnification.

In Data Table 4, note what makes the cells you have labeled in Step 5 look different from each other. Also record the total magnification needed to best view the cells.
Total magnification = (eyepiece lens power) x (objective lens power)
Replace the slide in the slide box.

Cover the microscope, and store it for future use.

pageData.title: Activity 4 Step 5 Photo
pageData.text:
Insert your photo of the mammalian ovary. The photo can be taken either through the eyepiece of the microscope or of a drawing done on paper. The following structures should be labeled in the photo:
  • Myometrium
  • Endometrium
  • Uterine gland
  • Columnar epithelium
Click on the browse button to upload the file

pageData.content: Figure 1. The parts of the testis
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Labeled cross section of the testis
Figure 2: A testis showing septa, blood vessels, interstitial cells, spermatozoa, and seminiferous tubules

pageData.content: Figure 3. The parts of the uterus and ovary
pageData.altText: Figure 3: The female reproductive system labeled, the uterus and ovaries scheme, and the phases of the menstrual cycle
Figure 4: Ovaries with primary oocyte, granulosa cells, follicle, antrum, and oocyte nuclei labeled
Figure 5: Uterine glands, endometrium/lamina propria, columnar epithelium, and myometrium in the uterus

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, set up the microscope. In Activities 1 through 4, you will place a slide on the stage and focus the tissue layers in the field of view. Then, record an image of the tissue under ideal magnification and identify the structures of the magnified tissue. Next, calculate the total magnification for ideal observation and compare the characteristics of each structure. You will repeat this until a total of 4 reproductive tissue slides have been observed.

pageData.content: How to Take a Picture Through a Microscope
How to Handle, Store, and Repair Microscope Slides

data.title: Antrum
data.content: The large space filled with follicular fluid that characterizes a secondary follicle

data.title: Broad ligaments
data.content: One of three types of ligaments by which ovaries are suspended in the abdominal pelvic area; they contain blood vessels supplying the ovary

data.title: Cervix
data.content: One of three major areas of the uterus; it separates the uterus from the vagina

data.title: Corpus luteum
data.content: The structure that forms from the collapsed tertiary follicle following oocyte release, which slowly degenerates and is absorbed into the surrounding tissue

data.title: Cortex
data.content: The outer layer of an organ

data.title: Efferent ductules
data.content: Small ducts that transport the mature sperm out of the testis

data.title: Endometrium
data.content: The innermost of three major layers of the uterus made up of simple columnar epithelium tissue on top of a layer of lamina propria

data.title: Follicular fluid
data.content: The fluid that surrounds the developing oocyte

data.title: Fundus
data.content: One of the three major areas of the uterus; it is located superior to the entry of the fallopian tubes

data.title: Gametes
data.content: cells that contain only half the genetic material of the organism

data.title: Gonads
data.content: The gamete-producing organs

data.title: Graafian follicle
data.content: The ovarian follicle that forms from the secondary follicle during the first 14 days of the ovarian cycle

data.title: Granulosa cells
data.content: The rounded, grainy-looking cells surrounding an oocyte

data.title: Interstitial cells
data.content: The cells in the testes that produce the male sex hormone testosterone

data.title: Lamina propria
data.content: A layer of loose connective tissue

data.title: Lobules
data.content: Areas of the testis that contain the seminiferous tubules

data.title: Medulla
data.content: The inner layer of an organ

data.title: Ova
data.content: The female gametes released from either of the female ovaries; they are capable of developing into a new organism when fertilized by a sperm cell; also called eggs; singular, ovum

data.title: Ovarian follicles
data.content: The site of production and maturation of the female ova (eggs); located in the ovarian cortex

data.title: Ovarian ligaments
data.content: One of three types of ligaments by which ovaries are suspended in the abdominal pelvic area; they contain blood vessels supplying the ovary

data.title: Ovaries
data.content: The female gonads and the site of female ova (egg) production

data.title: Parietal layer
data.content: The outer layer of the tunica vaginalis

data.title: Peritoneum
data.content: A membrane that lines the inside of the abdomen and pelvis

data.title: Primary follicle
data.content: The cuboidal cells that are produced by follicular cell division and surround the primary oocyte

data.title: Primary oocyte
data.content: A haploid cell with a large nucleus that starts the egg maturation process

data.title: Rete testis
data.content: The portion of the testis that connects the straight tubules to the efferent ductules

data.title: Scrotum
data.content: The pouch outside the body cavity that contains the male testes

data.title: Secondary follicle
data.content: The layers of granulosa cells that surround oocytes in mid-growth stages

data.title: Secondary sex characteristics
data.content: The various characteristics specific to females or males but not directly concerned with reproduction, such as breast development in females and chest hair in males

data.title: Seminiferous tubules
data.content: The ducts in the testis lined with epithelial cells and that produce the spermatozoa (sperm cells)

data.title: Septa
data.content: The fibrous partitions of the tunica albuginea in the testes

data.title: Sperm (spermatozoa)
data.content: The male gametes produced in male testes and that are capable of fertilizing female ova (eggs)

data.title: Straight tubule
data.content: The portion of the testis that connects each seminiferous tubule to the rete testis

data.title: Stratum basalis
data.content: The layer of the endometrium that creates a new stratum functionalis after menstruation ends

data.title: Stratum functionalis
data.content: The layer of the endometrium that is shed during each menstruation period

data.title: Suspensory ligaments
data.content: One of three types of ligaments by which ovaries are suspended in the abdominal pelvic area; they contain blood vessels supplying the ovary

data.title: Tertiary follicle
data.content: The ovarian follicle that forms from the secondary follicle during the first 14 days of the ovarian cycle

data.title: Tunica albuginea
data.content: The layer of dense connective tissue deep to the tunica vaginalis; it contains blood vessels to supply nutrients and oxygen to underyling testicular tissue, and lymph vessels to drain excess fluid from the testis

data.title: Tunica vaginalis
data.content: A two-layered tunic that covers each testis and has a similar structure to the peritoneum

data.title: Uterine body
data.content: The main portion of the uterus

data.title: Uterine glands
data.content: Glands in the endometrium that secrete a glycogen-rich mucous fluid during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle

data.title: Uterus
data.content: The organ to which a fertilized egg can attach and develop into a fetus

data.title: Vesicular follicle
data.content: The ovarian follicle that forms from the secondary follicle during the first 14 days of the ovarian cycle

data.title: Visceral layery
data.content: The inner layer of the tunica vaginalis
